content: Definition: "The status of the resource instance." Is this supposed to mean that this is the status of the data artifact, rather than the actual coverage? I don't think it is but it blurs the line a bit.
@Jay Lyle it is the status of the artifact. The coverage itself has an inception/expiry period but it doesn't become inactive as it remains relevant.

For this particular element in Coverage, would it be appropriate to keep the Coverage status active, when a Coverage period has elapsed? For instance if I had a Coverage with period of 2020-01-01 to 2020-12-30, and today is 2021-05-05, would that Coverage resource be active, or cancelled?

I have been leaning towards cancelled because it is no longer active, but I am very confused on the FHIR definition for this element.

@Andy Devitt It would be active, and it is one you would use if you were still trying to get a claim submitted without errors for a service provided on Dec 3 2020. If the Coverage record says what you mean it to say then it would be active, if not you may have created a new coverage record and marked the invalid one at inactive.
So the status pertains to the record, not the state of the coverage?
And the status of the coverage itself is not exposed because clinical systems typically have no clue? Might be good to capture that in the element rational.
Thank you for the guidance on this.
Andy Devitt has marked this topic as resolved.
